TEXT.English: [BOLD]Strategy:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Coca Plants[COLOR_REVERT] are endemic to highlands at tropical latitudes. They grow only on hilly [LINK=TERRAIN_SAVANNAH]Savannah[\LINK] terrain that is either open or overgrown by [LINK=FEATURE_JUNGLE]Jungle[\LINK], [LINK=FEATURE_FOREST]Forest[\LINK] or [LINK=FEATURE_LIGHT_FOREST]Light Forest[\LINK].[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Coca Leaves can refer to leaves of all four cultivated plants of the Coca family (Erythoxylaceae), native to western South America. In times both ancient and modern, these plants have been highly valued for their psychoactive properties, which can be experienced by chewing the leaves, making coca tea ("Mate de coca") out of it and, in modern times, chemically extracting the psychoactive agents to produce the drug Cocaine. Coca Leaves are an effective remedy against altitude sickness, and bestows upon its consumer a greater tolerance for hunger, thirst and fatigue. Apart from that, coca can be used as an anaesthetic as well, and due to its religious significance in indigenous cultures, many other properties are ascribed to it, some of which are supported by modern science.[PARAGRAPH:1] Coca Leaves have been used for medicinal, nutritional and religious purposes in the Andean region since prehistoric times, possibly as long as 8000 years before present time. It was during this long period that the ancestral coca plant was eventually domesticated, after which it diversified into the four modern species. In the Incan Empire, the plant was thought to have a divine origin, and its leaves were used as offerings, as a method of divination, similar to the reading of tea leaves in the old world, and also as preparation for prayers or religious ceremonies. It eventually spread to a large area, ranging from Colombia in the north to Chile in the south. [PARAGRAPH:2] After the Spanish conquest of the Incan Empire, the use of the leaf was tolerated by the Spanish, as it also enhanced the performance of forced laborers, but its religious use was prohibited, and the Spanish themselves were discouraged from using it. Though it was introduced in Europe in the 16th Century, it did not actually become popular until the 19th Century, when the first cocaine was produced.

TEXT.German: [BOLD]Strategie:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Cocapflanzen[COLOR_REVERT] sind in tropischen Breitengraden auf hügeliger [LINK=TERRAIN_SAVANNAH]Savanne[\LINK] beheimatet. Gelegentlich können besonders gute Anbaugebiete für Cocapflanzen auch von [LINK=FEATURE_JUNGLE]Dschungel[\LINK], [LINK=FEATURE_FOREST]Wald[\LINK] oder [LINK=FEATURE_LIGHT_FOREST]Buschland[\LINK] überwachsen sein.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Cocapflanzen[COLOR_REVERT] sind in den Höhenlagen tropischer Breitengrade beheimatet. Sie wachsen im Hügelland der [LINK=TERRAIN_SAVANNAH]Savanne[\LINK]. [PARAGRAPH:2]Der Begriff [LINK=YIELD_COCA_LEAVES]Cocablätter[\LINK] bezieht sich meist auf Blätter der kultivierten Planzen aus der Familie der Cocapflanzen (Erythoxylaceae), welche im westlichen Teil Südamerikas beheimatet sind. Sowohl in der alten Geschichte, wie auch in der modernen Zeit wurden diese Pflanzen sehr hoch geschätzt, da sie psychoaktive Substanzen beinhalten, die man durch das Kauen der Blätter oder durch den Konsum des daraus aufgebrühten Tees aufnehmen kann. In der heutigen Zeit, wird aus diesen Blättern auch die Droge Kokain gewonnen. Weniger bedenkliche Anwirkungen der Cocablätter sind aber beispielsweise die Anwendung in geringeren Mengen als Mittel gegen Höhenkrankheit oder gegen Hungergefühle, Durstgefühle oder Müdigkeit. Ausserdem kann Coca auch zur Betäubung von Schmerzen verwendet werden.[PARAGRAPH:1] Cocablätter wurden jeher in den Regionen der Anden zu relgiösen, medizinischen und nahrungsergänzenden Zwecken eingesetzt. Wahrscheinlich sogar weit länger als 8000 Jahre. In dieser langen Zeitperiode wurde die Cocapflanze irgendwann domestiziert. Heutzutage wird sie in vier unterschiedlichen Gattungen bzw. Unterarten gezüchtet. Das Imperium der Inkas glaubte an einen göttlichen Ursprung der Planze und verwendeten die Blätter als Opfergaben, aber auch als Mittel um die Zukunft voherzusagen oder einfach nur um Gebete und Zeremonien vorzubereiten. Die Pflanze breitete sich schliesslich über ein sehr grosses Gebiet von Kolumbien im Norden bis Chile im Süden aus. [PARAGRAPH:2] Nach der spanischen Eroberung des Inkareiches wurde die Einnahme der Pflanze weiterhin von den Spaniern toleriert, da sie die Leistung der Zwangsarbeiter steigerte. Die religiöse Verwendung der Pflanze wurde aber verboten. Den Spaniern selbst wurde davon abgeraten die Blätter zu konsumieren. Obwohlb bereits im 16ten Jahrhundert Cocablätter in Europa bekannt waren, erlangten diese dort zu dieser Zeit nie Beliebtheit. Dies änderte sich erst als im 19ten Jahrhundert Kokain entdeckt wurde.
TEXT.Italian: [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Coca Plants[COLOR_REVERT] are endemic to highlands at tropical latitudes. They grow only on hilly [LINK=TERRAIN_SAVANNAH]Savannah[\LINK] terrain. [PARAGRAPH:2][LINK=YIELD_COCA_LEAVES]Coca Leaves[\LINK] can refer to leaves of all four cultivated plants of the Coca family (Erythoxylaceae), native to western South America. In times both ancient and modern, these plants have been highly valued for their psychoactive properties, which can be experienced by chewing the leaves, making coca tea ("Mate de coca") out of it and, in modern times, chemically extracting the psychoactive agents to produce the drug Cocaine. Coca Leaves are an effective remedy against altitude sickness, and bestows upon its consumer a greater tolerance for hunger, thirst and fatigue. Apart from that, coca can be used as an anaesthetic as well, and due to its religious significance in indigenous cultures, many other properties are ascribed to it, some of which are supported by modern science.[PARAGRAPH:1] Coca Leaves have been used for medicinal, nutritional and religious purposes in the Andean region since prehistoric times, possibly as long as 8000 years before present time. It was during this long period that the ancestral coca plant was eventually domesticated, after which it diversified into the four modern species. In the Incan Empire, the plant was thought to have a divine origin, and its leaves were used as offerings, as a method of divination, similar to the reading of tea leaves in the old world, and also as preparation for prayers or religious ceremonies. It eventually spread to a large area, ranging from Colombia in the north to Chile in the south. [PARAGRAPH:2] After the Spanish conquest of the Incan Empire, the use of the leaf was tolerated by the Spanish, as it also enhanced the performance of forced laborers, but its religious use was prohibited, and the Spanish themselves were discouraged from using it. Though it was introduced in Europe in the 16th Century, it did not actually become popular until the 19th Century, when the first cocaine was produced.

Unterarten gezüchtet. Das Imperium der Inkas glaubte an einen göttlichen Ursprung der Planze und verwendeten die Blätter als Opfergaben, aber auch als Mittel um die Zukunft voherzusagen oder einfach nur um Gebete und Zeremonien vorzubereiten. Die Pflanze breitete sich schliesslich über ein sehr grosses Gebiet von Kolumbien im Norden bis Chile im Süden aus. [PARAGRAPH:2] Nach der spanischen Eroberung des Inkareiches wurde die Einnahme der Pflanze weiterhin von den Spaniern toleriert, da sie die Leistung der Zwangsarbeiter steigerte. Die religiöse Verwendung der Pflanze wurde aber verboten. Den Spaniern selbst wurde davon abgeraten die Blätter zu konsumieren. Obwohlb bereits im 16ten Jahrhundert Cocablätter in Europa bekannt waren, erlangten diese dort zu dieser Zeit nie Beliebtheit. Dies änderte sich erst als im 19ten Jahrhundert Kokain entdeckt wurde.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Coca Leaves can refer to leaves of all four cultivated plants of the Coca family (Erythoxylaceae), native to western South America. In times both ancient and modern, these plants have been highly valued for their psychoactive properties, which can be experienced by chewing the leaves, making coca tea ("Mate de coca") out of it and, in modern times, chemically extracting the psychoactive agents to produce the drug Cocaine. Coca Leaves are an effective remedy against altitude sickness, and bestows upon its consumer a greater tolerance for hunger, thirst and fatigue. Apart from that, coca can be used as an anaesthetic as well, and due to its religious significance in indigenous cultures, many other properties are ascribed to it, some of which are supported by modern science.[PARAGRAPH:1] Coca Leaves have been used for medicinal, nutritional and religious purposes in the Andean region since prehistoric times, possibly as long as 8000 years before present time. It was during this long period that the ancestral coca plant was eventually domesticated, after which it diversified into the four modern species. In the Incan Empire, the plant was thought to have a divine origin, and its leaves were used as offerings, as a method of divination, similar to the reading of tea leaves in the old world, and also as preparation for prayers or religious ceremonies. It eventually spread to a large area, ranging from Colombia in the north to Chile in the south. [PARAGRAPH:2] After the Spanish conquest of the Incan Empire, the use of the leaf was tolerated by the Spanish, as it also enhanced the performance of forced laborers, but its religious use was prohibited, and the Spanish themselves were discouraged from using it. Though it was introduced in Europe in the 16th Century, it did not actually become popular until the 19th Century, when the first cocaine was produced.

TEXT.English: [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Coca Collectors[COLOR_REVERT] can gather [LINK=YIELD_COCA_LEAVES]Coca Leaves[\LINK] from hilly [LINK=TERRAIN_SAVANNAH]Savannah[\LINK] regions with little or no vegetation. The yield will be higher when the [LINK=BONUS_COCA]Coca Plants[\LINK] bonus is present, and can also be increased by constructing [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_COLLECTORS_POST2]Coca Posts[\LINK]. If unspecialized colonists practice this profession long enough, they will eventually become [LINK=UNIT_COCA_COLLECTOR]Expert Coca Collectors[\LINK], who produce double the amount of Coca Leaves any other colonist would produce.
TEXT.French: [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Coca Collectors[COLOR_REVERT] can gather [LINK=YIELD_COCA_LEAVES]Coca Leaves[\LINK] from hilly [LINK=TERRAIN_SAVANNAH]Savannah[\LINK] regions with little or no vegetation. If unspecialized colonists practice this profession long enough, they will eventually become [LINK=UNIT_COCA_COLLECTOR]Expert Coca Collectors[\LINK], who produce double the amount of Coca Leaves any other colonist would produce.
TEXT.German: [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Cocasammler[COLOR_REVERT] können [LINK=YIELD_COCA_LEAVES]Cocablätter[\LINK] von Hügeln auf Regionen der [LINK=TERRAIN_SAVANNAH]Savannah[\LINK] sammeln. Der Ertrag ist höher, wenn es auf dem Feld auch die Bonusresource [LINK=BONUS_COCA]Cocapflanzen[\LINK] gibt und kann noch weiter erhöht werden, wenn man darauf die Geländeverbesserung [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_COLLECTORS_POST2]Cocasammelstelle[\LINK] errichtet. Wenn ein nicht spezialisierter Kolonist lange genug diesen Beruf ausübt, kann er irgendwann zu einem [LINK=UNIT_COCA_COLLECTOR]Erfahrenen Cocasammler[\LINK] werden, der doppelt soviele Cocablätter ernten kann.

TEXT.English: [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Expert Coca Collectors[COLOR_REVERT] are specialists in growing, maintaining and harvesting [LINK=BONUS_COCA]Coca Plants[\LINK]. When assigned to gather [LINK=YIELD_COCA_LEAVES]Coca Leaves[\LINK], Expert Coca Collectors will generate twice as much Coca Leaves as other colonists. Some native villages may be willing to teach this profession to European colonists, and they can also be [LINK=CONCEPT_TRAINING]Trained[\LINK] in a colony with a [LINK=BUILDING_COLLEGE]College[\LINK] or one of its upgrades.
TEXT.French: [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Expert Coca Collectors[COLOR_REVERT] are specialists in growing, maintaining and harvesting [LINK=BONUS_COCA]Coca Plants[\LINK]. When assigned to gather [LINK=YIELD_COCA_LEAVES]Coca Leaves[\LINK], Expert Coca Collectors will generate twice as much Coca Leaves as other colonists. Some native villages may be willing to teach this profession to European colonists, and they can also be [LINK=CONCEPT_TRAINING]Trained[\LINK] in a colony with a [LINK=BUILDING_COLLEGE]College[\LINK] or one of its upgrades.
TEXT.German: [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Erfahrene Cocasammler[COLOR_REVERT] sind Spezialisten im Heranziehen und Ernten der Blätter der [LINK=BONUS_COCA]Cocapflanze[\LINK]. Wenn man ihnen befiehlt [LINK=YIELD_COCA_LEAVES]Cocablätter[\LINK] zu sammeln, sind Erfahrene Cocasammler doppelt so effektiv darin, wie andere Kolonisten. Einige Dörfer der Ureinwohner können europäischen Kolonisten diese Spezalisierung des Berufs Cocasammler beibringen.

TEXT.English: [TAB][H1]BLADES[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Strategy:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Blades[COLOR_REVERT] are relatively cheap weapons that can be used as equipment by [LINK=PROFESSION_HEAVY_CAVALRY]Cavalrymen[\LINK], as well as most military ships.[PARAGRAPH:1]To craft Blades, a colonist can convert [LINK=YIELD_ORE]Ore[\LINK] into Blades when he is assigned the [LINK=PROFESSION_BLADESMITH]Bladesmith[\LINK] profession in a [LINK=BUILDING_BLACKSMITH_HOUSE]Blacksmith's House[\LINK] or any of its upgrades. The output of Blades can be doubled by employing [LINK=UNIT_BLACKSMITH]Master Blacksmiths[\LINK] for this purpose.[NEWLINE]For more information, see [LINK=CONCEPT_GUNS]Guns, Cannons and Blades[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT] Blades[COLOR_REVERT] can refer to any weapon or tool with a sharp point or a sharp edge, meant for cutting or puncturing.[NEWLINE]The art of creating cutting devices is one of the oldest crafts of humanity, so old, in fact, that even non-human hominids like Neanderthals and Homo Erectus are known to have used blade- or axelike artifacts. This was a vital invention in prehistory, as cutting and stabbing devices could be used for food preparation, hunting, warfare, art, digging and creation of other tools.[NEWLINE]Blades need to be crafted from hard, tough material, which is why they are so often preserved as archeological artifacts. Because of the abundance of preserved blades, the material of which they were crafted have been used to name the three different eras of ancient history: the Stone Age, the Bronze Age and ultimately the Iron Age.[NEWLINE]Bladed weapons, such as swords, axes, spears and knives, have been the regular weapon for hand-to-hand combat for the most part of history, and they remained common in warfare until the first effective gunpowder weapons had been invented, such as handguns. They became obsolete over the course of the 19th Century, being preserved mostly as ceremonial weapons.[PARAGRAPH:2]At the time Columbus discovered America, melee weapons were still the default weapons of choice of European armies, though gunpowder weapons were becoming steadily more reliable and effective. The conquistadores combined gunpowder weapons, such as arquebuses and muskets, with melee weapons, usually side-swords or in some cases halberds, and non-gunpowdered range weapons such as crossbows.[NEWLINE]This usually gave the Europeans a huge military advantage over the native nations they encountered. While many native civilizations were quite proficient in the working of metals, they applied this technology mostly to the crafting of ceremonial objects, jewels, tools and art, not weapons for warfare. Bladed weapons were usually crafted from wood, flint or obsidian. There were exceptions to this, though, most prominently the empires of the Tarascans and the Incas, who crafted swords of copper and bronze. However, these still were no match for the iron and steel weapons of the invaders.[PARAGRAPH:2]Over the course of the colonial age, blades remained vital weapons for most armies. Examples of swords used in this period include the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT] side-sword[COLOR_REVERT], a small sword that allowed its wielder a great amount of agility in combat and was primarily useful for self-defense. A similar design was the somewhat more modern [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT] rapier[COLOR_REVERT], featuring a long, thin blade and a hilt that provides protection for the hand holding it, which due to its design, was primarily designed for thrusting, not so much for slashing.[NEWLINE]Though blades were used in official warfare as well, they achieved most of their fame as the weapon of choice for pirates. The combination of a side-sword and a buckler, a small shield, gave rise to the name "swashbuckler," because of the combination of the swashing of the sword through the air and the noise it makes when hitting a buckler.

Because of the abundance of preserved blades, the material of which they were crafted have been used to name the three different eras of ancient history: the Stone Age, the Bronze Age and ultimately the Iron Age.[NEWLINE]Bladed weapons, such as swords, axes, spears and knives, have been the regular weapon for hand-to-hand combat for the most part of history, and they remained common in warfare until the first effective gunpowder weapons had been invented, such as handguns. They became obsolete over the course of the 19th Century, being preserved mostly as ceremonial weapons.[PARAGRAPH:2]At the time Columbus discovered America, melee weapons were still the default weapons of choice of European armies, though gunpowder weapons were becoming steadily more reliable and effective. The conquistadores combined gunpowder weapons, such as arquebuses and muskets, with melee weapons, usually side-swords or in some cases halberds, and non-gunpowdered range weapons such as crossbows.[NEWLINE]This usually gave the Europeans a huge military advantage over the native nations they encountered. While many native civilizations were quite proficient in the working of metals, they applied this technology mostly to the crafting of ceremonial objects, jewels, tools and art, not weapons for warfare. Bladed weapons were usually crafted from wood, flint or obsidian. There were exceptions to this, though, most prominently the empires of the Tarascans and the Incas, who crafted swords of copper and bronze. However, these still were no match for the iron and steel weapons of the invaders.[PARAGRAPH:2]Over the course of the colonial age, blades remained vital weapons for most armies. Examples of swords used in this period include the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT] side-sword[COLOR_REVERT], a small sword that allowed its wielder a great amount of agility in combat and was primarily useful for self-defense. A similar design was the somewhat more modern [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT] rapier[COLOR_REVERT], featuring a long, thin blade and a hilt that provides protection for the hand holding it, which due to its design, was primarily designed for thrusting, not so much for slashing.[NEWLINE]Though blades were used in official warfare as well, they achieved most of their fame as the weapon of choice for pirates. The combination of a side-sword and a buckler, a small shield, gave rise to the name "swashbuckler," because of the combination of the swashing of the sword through the air and the noise it makes when hitting a buckler.
TEXT.German: [TAB][H1]Klingenwaffen[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Strategie:[\BOLD][NEWLINE][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Klingenwaffen[COLOR_REVERT] sind verlgeichsweise günstige Waffen. Militärberufe benötigen gerinere Mengen an Klingenwaffen, wie beispielsweise [LINK=PROFESSION_HEAVY_CAVALRY]Kavalleristen[\LINK]. Auch einige Kriegsschiffe benötigen zum Bau kleinere Mengen an Klingenwaffen.[PARAGRAPH:1]Um Klingenwaffen herzustellen, muss einem Kolonisten der Beruf [LINK=PROFESSION_BLADESMITH]Klingenschmied[\LINK] in der [LINK=BUILDING_BLACKSMITH_HOUSE]Dorfschmiede[\LINK] oder deren Ausbaustufen zugewiesen werden. Zur Herstellung von Klingenwaffen wird [LINK=YIELD_ORE]Eisenerz[\LINK] benötigt. [LINK=UNIT_BLACKSMITH]Meister Schmiede[\LINK] sind am geschicktesten in der Herstellung von Klingenwaffen.[NEWLINE]Für weiter Informationen siehe [LINK=CONCEPT_GUNS]Schusswaffen, Kannonen und Klingen[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][NEWLINE]Der Begriff [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Klingenwaffe[COLOR_REVERT] kann sich auf jegliche Waffe beziehen, die eine eine Scharfe Schneide hat. [NEWLINE]Die Kunst der Herstellung von Klingen ist eines der ältesten Handwerke, die der Menschheit bekannt sind. Sie ist sogar so alt, dass sogar Neandertaler und der Homo Erectus bereits Klingenwaffen besassen. Es war eine lebenswichtige Erfindung in der Vorgeschichte, da sie für die Jagd, zur Zubereitung des Essens, zur Herstellung anderer Werkzeuge aber auch zu kämpferischen Zwecken benötigt wurde.[NEWLINE]Klingen müssen aus harten und robusten Materialien hergestellt werden und sind dadurch oft der Archeologie erhalten geblieben. Sie haben sogar ultimativ die Einteilung der Vorzeit in Steinzeitalter, Bronzezeitalter und Eisenzeitalter bestimmt.[NEWLINE]Klingenwaffen, wie Schwerter, Speere und Messer haben bis zu der Erfindung von Schusswaffen die Kämpfe und Schlachten der Geschichte bestimmt. Aber bereits im 19ten Jahrhundert hatten sie jegliche entscheidende Rolle in der Kriegsführung verloren und dienten fortan eher zum Sport oder zu zeremoniellen Zwecken. [PARAGRAPH:2]Zu der Zeit als Kolumbus Amerika entdeckte, waren Klingenwaffen immer noch die Hauptwaffe europäischer Armeen, obwohl Feuerwaffen bereits bekannt waren und nach und nach auch immer effektiver und zuverlässiger wurden. Die Konquistadores kombinierten Feuerwaffen, wie Musketen und Arkebusen mit Klingenwaffen, wie Schwerter und Helebarden aber auch mit anderen Waffen, wie beispielsweise Armbrüsten und erhielten dadurch erhebliche Vorteile gegen die viel schlechter ausgerüsteten Ureinwohner denen sie begegneten. [NEWLINE]Obwohl einige der Zivilisation der Ureiwohner bereits mit Metallen arbeiteten, wandten sie diese Technicken meist nicht zur Herstellung von Waffen and, sonder eher zur Herstellung von Objekten für das Handwerk oder religiöse Zeremonien. Waffen wurden meist aus Holz, Stein oder Materialien wie Obsidian hergestellt. Es gab hier nur wenige Ausnahmen, wie beispielsweise die Imperien der Taraskan oder der Inkas, die Klingen auch aus Kupfer oder Bronze ferigten. Diese stellten aber die eisernen Waffen der europäischen Invasoren ebenfalls nicht vor eine Herausforderung.[PARAGRAPH:2]Während des Kolonialzeitalters blieben Klingen weiterhin ein essentieller Teilder Bewaffnung der Armeen. Ein gutes Beispiel hierfür ist die Gattunt der Seitenschwerter oder in der etwas moderneren Ausführung der Rapiere.[NEWLINE]Auch bei Piraten waren Klingen, vorallem Schwerter, zu dieser Zeit sehr beliebt.

This was a vital invention in prehistory, as cutting and stabbing devices could be used for food preparation, hunting, warfare, art, digging and creation of other tools.[NEWLINE]Blades need to be crafted from hard, tough material, which is why they are so often preserved as archeological artifacts. Because of the abundance of preserved blades, the material of which they were crafted have been used to name the three different eras of ancient history: the Stone Age, the Bronze Age and ultimately the Iron Age.[NEWLINE]Bladed weapons, such as swords, axes, spears and knives, have been the regular weapon for hand-to-hand combat for the most part of history, and they remained common in warfare until the first effective gunpowder weapons had been invented, such as handguns. They became obsolete over the course of the 19th Century, being preserved mostly as ceremonial weapons.[PARAGRAPH:2]At the time Columbus discovered America, melee weapons were still the default weapons of choice of European armies, though gunpowder weapons were becoming steadily more reliable and effective. The conquistadores combined gunpowder weapons, such as arquebuses and muskets, with melee weapons, usually side-swords or in some cases halberds, and non-gunpowdered range weapons such as crossbows.[NEWLINE]This usually gave the Europeans a huge military advantage over the native nations they encountered. While many native civilizations were quite proficient in the working of metals, they applied this technology mostly to the crafting of ceremonial objects, jewels, tools and art, not weapons for warfare. Bladed weapons were usually crafted from wood, flint or obsidian. There were exceptions to this, though, most prominently the empires of the Tarascans and the Incas, who crafted swords of copper and bronze. However, these still were no match for the iron and steel weapons of the invaders.[PARAGRAPH:2]Over the course of the colonial age, blades remained vital weapons for most armies. Examples of swords used in this period include the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT] side-sword[COLOR_REVERT], a small sword that allowed its wielder a great amount of agility in combat and was primarily useful for self-defense. A similar design was the somewhat more modern [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT] rapier[COLOR_REVERT], featuring a long, thin blade and a hilt that provides protection for the hand holding it, which due to its design, was primarily designed for thrusting, not so much for slashing.[NEWLINE]Though blades were used in official warfare as well, they achieved most of their fame as the weapon of choice for pirates. The combination of a side-sword and a buckler, a small shield, gave rise to the name "swashbuckler," because of the combination of the swashing of the sword through the air and the noise it makes when hitting a buckler.

TEXT.English: You can convert [LINK=YIELD_ORE]Ore[\LINK] into [LINK=YIELD_BLADES]Blades[\LINK] by assigning colonists to the [LINK=PROFESSION_BLADESMITH]Bladesmith[\LINK] profession in the [LINK=BUILDING_BLACKSMITH_HOUSE]Blacksmith's House[\LINK] or one of its upgrades. By assigning a specialist [LINK=UNIT_BLACKSMITH]Master Blacksmith[\LINK] to this profession, the output of Blades is even doubled, as long as enough Ore is available.[PARAGRAPH:1]For more information, see [LINK=CONCEPT_GUNS]Guns, Cannons and Blades[\LINK]
TEXT.French: You can convert [LINK=YIELD_ORE]Ore[\LINK] into [LINK=YIELD_BLADES]Blades[\LINK] by assigning colonists to the [LINK=PROFESSION_BLADESMITH]Bladesmith[\LINK] profession in the [LINK=BUILDING_BLACKSMITH_HOUSE]Blacksmith's House[\LINK] or one of its upgrades. By assigning a specialist [LINK=UNIT_BLACKSMITH]Master Blacksmith[\LINK] to this profession, the output of Blades is even doubled, as long as enough Ore is available.[PARAGRAPH:1]For more information, see [LINK=CONCEPT_GUNS]Guns, Cannons and Blades[\LINK]
TEXT.German: Man kann [LINK=YIELD_ORE]Eisenerz[\LINK] in [LINK=YIELD_BLADES]Klingenwaffen[\LINK] umwandeln, wenn man einem Siedler den Beruf des [LINK=PROFESSION_BLADESMITH]Klingenschmieds[\LINK] zuweist, welcher in der [LINK=BUILDING_BLACKSMITH_HOUSE]Dorfschmiede[\LINK] oder einer ihrer Ausbauten ausgeübt wird. Wird dieser Beruf einem [LINK=UNIT_BLACKSMITH]Meisterschmied[\LINK] zugewiesen, so erhöht sich die Produktion der Klingen um das doppelte, so lange genug Eisenerz verfügbar ist.
TEXT.Italian: You can convert [LINK=YIELD_ORE]Ore[\LINK] into [LINK=YIELD_BLADES]Blades[\LINK] by assigning colonists to the [LINK=PROFESSION_BLADESMITH]Bladesmith[\LINK] profession in the [LINK=BUILDING_BLACKSMITH_HOUSE]Blacksmith's House[\LINK] or one of its upgrades. By assigning a specialist [LINK=UNIT_BLACKSMITH]Master Blacksmith[\LINK] to this profession, the output of Blades is even doubled, as long as enough Ore is available.
TEXT.Spanish: You can convert [LINK=YIELD_ORE]Ore[\LINK] into [LINK=YIELD_BLADES]Blades[\LINK] by assigning colonists to the [LINK=PROFESSION_BLADESMITH]Bladesmith[\LINK] profession in the [LINK=BUILDING_BLACKSMITH_HOUSE]Blacksmith's House[\LINK] or one of its upgrades. By assigning a specialist [LINK=UNIT_BLACKSMITH]Master Blacksmith[\LINK] to this profession, the output of Blades is even doubled, as long as enough Ore is available.

TEXT.English: The skilled Blacksmith is as much a musician as a craftsman. The heating, hammering, and cooling of the raw metal requires a learned rhythm that can only be attained through years of practice. Imagine trying to build a home without nails, hammers or saws, or clearing a field without an axe, and you begin to see why a skilled Blacksmith is critical to the success of a growing colony.
TEXT.French: The skilled Blacksmith is as much a musician as a craftsman. The heating, hammering, and cooling of the raw metal requires a learned rhythm that can only be attained through years of practice. Imagine trying to build a home without nails, hammers or saws, or clearing a field without an axe, and you begin to see why a skilled Blacksmith is critical to the success of a growing colony.
TEXT.German: Ein fähiger Schmied ist ebenso Musiker wie Handwerker. Das Erhitzen, Schlagen und Kühlen des rohen Metalls verlangt nach einem steten Rhythmus, der nur in den Jahren der Ausbildung erlernt werden kann. Wenn man sich vorstellt, wie ein Haus ohne Nägel, Hämmer und Sägen gebaut oder wie ein Wald ohne Axt gelichtet werden soll, begreift man schnell, warum ein Schmied für den Erfolg einer wachsenden Kolonie unerlässlich ist.
TEXT.Italian: Un abile fabbro è tanto musicista quanto artigiano. Riscaldare, martellare e raffreddare il metallo grezzo richiede un ritmo che si può imparare solamente attraverso anni di pratica. Immagina di dover costruire una casa senza chiodi, martelli o seghe, o di dover abbattere un albero senza un'ascia, e comincerai a capire perché un abile fabbro è fondamentale per il successo di una colonia in crescita.
TEXT.Spanish: El habilidoso Herrero tiene tanto de artesano como de músico. El calentamiento, martilleo y enfriamiento del metal necesita de un ritmo concreto que solo puede conseguirse con años de práctica. Solo hay que intentar imaginar cómo construir una casa sin clavos, martillos o sierras o cómo desbrozar un campo sin un hacha para empezar a darse cuenta de por qué un buen Herrero es indispensable para que una colonia prospere.

TEXT.English: The Coat Maker profession was a highly lucrative one in the New World. There were literally thousands of undiscovered animals waiting in the backwoods of the Americas. And, much to the coat maker's favor, many had soft, easily processed skins, making the Coat Maker's job even easier. Such was the value of New World furs that outside of major population centers, they were often used as a form of currency.
TEXT.French: The Coat Maker profession was a highly lucrative one in the New World. There were literally thousands of undiscovered animals waiting in the backwoods of the Americas. And, much to the coat maker's favor, many had soft, easily processed skins, making the Coat Maker's job even easier. Such was the value of New World furs that outside of major population centers, they were often used as a form of currency.
TEXT.German: Der Trapper oder der Jäger tauschte seine Felle bei Händlern gegen Gold, Nahrung, Kugeln, Schießpulver oder andere Vorräte ein. Dieser Händler waren oft zugleich Pelzhändler und stellten aus den Fellen einfache Übermäntel oder Umhänge her. Manchmal bearbeiteten sie die Felle aber auch nur, reinigten und schnitten sie zu und verkauften sie dann nach Europa.
TEXT.Italian: Nel Nuovo Mondo, quella del fabbricante di mantelli era una professione estremamente proficua. Esistevano letteralmente migliaia di animali sconosciuti nei boschi delle Americhe e molti avevano pellicce morbide e facilmente lavorabili, rendendo il lavoro del fabbricante di mantelli ancora più facile. E il valore delle pellicce del Nuovo Mondo era tale che, al di fuori dei più grandi centri abitati, venivano spesso utilizzate come una forma di valuta.
TEXT.Spanish: La profesión de Confeccionista de abrigos era una de las más lucrativas en el Nuevo Mundo. Había literalmente miles de animales por descubrir esperando en las regiones más apartadas de las Américas. Y, para suerte del Confeccionista de abrigos, tenían Pieles suaves y fáciles de procesar, lo cual les facilitaba aún más el trabajo. Tal era el valor de las Pieles del Nuevo Mundo que, fuera de los núcleos de población principales, se usaban a menudo como moneda de cambio.

TEXT.English: Moving a colonist to work in a [LINK=BUILDING_FUR_TRADERS_HOUSE]Fur Trader's House[\LINK], [LINK=BUILDING_FUR_TRADING_POST]Fur Trading Post[\LINK] or [LINK=BUILDING_FUR_FACTORY]Coat Factory[\LINK] gives you the possibility to assign the colonist to the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Premium Coat Maker[COLOR_REVERT] profession, and make him use [LINK=YIELD_PREMIUM_FUR]Premium Fur[\LINK] to make [LINK=YIELD_PREMIUM_COATS]Premium Coats[\LINK]. Assigning a [LINK=UNIT_FUR_TRADER]Master Fur Trader[\LINK] to the job will increase the number of [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Premium Coats[COLOR_REVERT] created each turn, but it will also up the number of [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Premium Furs[COLOR_REVERT] consumed.
TEXT.French: Moving a colonist to work in a [LINK=BUILDING_FUR_TRADERS_HOUSE]Fur Trader's House[\LINK], [LINK=BUILDING_FUR_TRADING_POST]Fur Trading Post[\LINK] or [LINK=BUILDING_FUR_FACTORY]Coat Factory[\LINK] gives you the possibility to assign the colonist to the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Premium Coat Maker[COLOR_REVERT] profession, and make him use [LINK=YIELD_PREMIUM_FUR]Premium Fur[\LINK] to make [LINK=YIELD_PREMIUM_COATS]Premium Coats[\LINK]. Assigning a [LINK=UNIT_FUR_TRADER]Master Fur Trader[\LINK] to the job will increase the number of [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Premium Coats[COLOR_REVERT] created each turn, but it will also up the number of [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Premium Furs[COLOR_REVERT] consumed.
TEXT.German: Wenn man einen Bürger anweist, in einer [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Pelzhändlerhütte[COLOR_REVERT], einem [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Pelzhandelsposten[COLOR_REVERT] oder einer [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Pelzwarenfabrik[COLOR_REVERT] zu arbeiten, nimmt der Bürger den Pelzhändlerberuf an. Weist man dem Beruf einen [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Meisterpelzhändler[COLOR_REVERT] zu, steigert das die Produktion von [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Pelzwaren[COLOR_REVERT] um 100 Prozent. Der Verbrauch an [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Fellen[COLOR_REVERT] steigt entsprechend.
TEXT.Italian: Se mandi un colono a lavorare in una [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]casa del pellicciaio[COLOR_REVERT], un [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]negozio di pellicce[COLOR_REVERT] o una [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]fabbrica di mantelli[COLOR_REVERT], questi assumerà la professione di fabbricante di mantelli. Se assegni il lavoro a un [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]mastro pellicciaio[COLOR_REVERT] aumenterai il numero di [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]mantelli[COLOR_REVERT] creati ogni turno, ma anche il numero di [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]pellicce[COLOR_REVERT] consumate.
TEXT.Spanish: Meter a un Colono en una [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Casa del peletero[COLOR_REVERT], una [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Peletería[COLOR_REVERT] o una [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Fábrica de abrigos[COLOR_REVERT] asignará al colono a la profesión de Confeccionista de abrigos. Asignar a un [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Maestro peletero[COLOR_REVERT] al puesto aumentará la cantidad de [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Abrigos[COLOR_REVERT] creados cada turno, pero también el número de [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Pieles[COLOR_REVERT] consumidas.

TEXT.English: When assigning a citizen to any water tile with [LINK=BONUS_SEA_OTTERS]Sea Otters[\LINK], you may opt for your colonist to adopt the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Sea Otter Trapper[COLOR_REVERT] profession, which will provide your colony with fresh [LINK=YIELD_PREMIUM_FUR]Premium Furs[\LINK]! If you assign an [LINK=UNIT_TRAPPER]Expert Trapper[\LINK] to this profession, it will significantly increase the number of Premium Furs you receive.
TEXT.French: When assigning a citizen to any water tile with [LINK=BONUS_SEA_OTTERS]Sea Otters[\LINK], you may opt for your colonist to adopt the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Sea Otter Trapper[COLOR_REVERT] profession, which will provide your colony with fresh [LINK=YIELD_PREMIUM_FUR]Premium Furs[\LINK]! If you assign an [LINK=UNIT_TRAPPER]Expert Trapper[\LINK] to this profession, it will significantly increase the number of Premium Furs you receive.
TEXT.German: Auf manchen Geländefeldern können Bürger wertvolle Rohstoffe gewinnen, die direkt exportiert oder in noch wertvollere Fertigwaren verwandelt werden können. Setzt man im Stadtbildschirm einen Bürger auf einem Tundrafeld mit [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Taiga[COLOR_REVERT] ein, kann man ihm den Beruf des [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Trappers[COLOR_REVERT] zuweisen. Gleiches gilt für Vorkommen von Seeottern oder Bibern.Er gewinnt dann [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Premium Felle[COLOR_REVERT], die in Pelzhändlereien zu Pelzwaren veredelt werden können.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Weist man einem [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Erfahrenen Trapper[COLOR_REVERT] den Beruf des Trappers zu, gewinnt er doppelt soviel von diesem Rohstoff als ein Freier Kolonist.
TEXT.Italian: Quando mandi un cittadino a lavorare caselle di tundra, di neve o qualsiasi casella con della foresta, puoi decidere di fargli svolgere la professione di cacciatore di pellicce, con cui procurerà nuove [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]pellicce[COLOR_REVERT] alla tua colonia! Se dai tale incarico a un [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]cacciatore esperto[COLOR_REVERT] farai aumentare in maniera significativa il numero di pellicce che otterrai.
TEXT.Spanish: Cuando asignéis a un ciudadano a una casilla de tundra o de nieve o a cualquier otra con bosque, podéis optar por convertirlo en un Trampero de pieles, que proporcionará a vuestra colonia [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Pieles[COLOR_REVERT] frescas. Si asignáis a un [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Trampero de pieles experto[COLOR_REVERT] esta profesión, aumentará sustancialmente el número de Pieles que recibáis.

TEXT.English: The sea otter is a marine mammal native to the coasts of the northern and eastern North Pacific Ocean. Adult sea otters typically weigh between 14 and 45 kg (30 and 100 lb), making them the heaviest members of the weasel family, but among the smallest marine mammals. Unlike most marine mammals, the sea otter's primary form of insulation is an exceptionally thick coat of fur, the densest in the animal kingdom. Although it can walk on land, the sea otter lives mostly in the ocean.[PARAGRAPH:1]The sea otter inhabits offshore environments, where it dives to the sea floor to forage. It preys mostly on marine invertebrates such as sea urchins, various molluscs and crustaceans, and some species of fish. Its foraging and eating habits are noteworthy in several respects. First, its use of rocks to dislodge prey and to open shells makes it one of the few mammal species to use tools. In most of its range, it is a keystone species, controlling sea urchin populations which would otherwise inflict extensive damage to kelp forest ecosystems. Its diet includes prey species that are also valued by humans as food, leading to conflicts between sea otters and fisheries.[PARAGRAPH:1]Sea otters, whose numbers were once estimated at 150,000 to 300,000, were hunted extensively for their fur between 1741 and 1911, and the world population fell to 1,000 to 2,000 individuals in a fraction of their historic range. A subsequent international ban on hunting, conservation efforts, and reintroduction programs into previously populated areas have contributed to numbers rebounding, and the species now occupies about two-thirds of its former range. The recovery of the sea otter is considered an important success in marine conservation, although populations in the Aleutian Islands and California have recently declined or have plateaued at depressed levels. For these reasons, the sea otter remains classified as an endangered species.

For these reasons, the sea otter remains classified as an endangered species.
TEXT.German: Der [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Seeotter[COLOR_REVERT] ist eine Raubtierart aus der Unterfamilie der Otter (Lutrinae). Er ist neben dem Küstenotter des Südpazifiks die einzige Otterart, die nur im Meer lebt. Seeotter gelten als intelligent und lernfähig, bekannt sind sie vor allem wegen des regelmäßigen Gebrauchs von Werkzeugen. Die Art war bis Anfang des 20. Jahrhunderts wegen ihres Fells fast ausgerottet; nach dem Jagdverbot im Jahr 1911 erholten sich die Bestände wieder.
